facts.text: Appellants were police constables at the time of the occurrence.
Appellants convicted by Special Judge of Delhi under s. 120B and s. 224/109 of IPC and s. 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.
Sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment under s. 5(2) PCA and nine months RI under each of ss. 120B and 224/109 IPC, sentences to run concurrently.
Appeals to Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi dismissed on November 16, 1956.

Prosecution case: Appellants conspired at Delhi with Ram Saran Das (approver), M.P. Khare, Nand Parkash Kapur and Murari between 6th and 16th November 1955 to bring about escape from lawful custody of M.P. Khare, undertrial prisoner; agreed to accept Rs. 1,000 each and other pecuniary advantages as illegal gratification; abetted the escape and accepted illegal gratification from Nand Parkash Kapur.
Findings of courts below: M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody; appellants enabled him to do so; received money as illegal gratification.
Pardon tendered to approver Ram Saran Das by District Magistrate of Delhi under s. 337 CrPC on 1-12-1955.
Prosecution witnesses Mela Ram (PW 6) and Shiv Parshad (PW 7) gave evidence; not accomplices.
No test identification parade of appellants held.
Single charge framed under ss. 120B, 224/109 IPC and s. 5(2) PCA; objection to joinder raised but abandoned by appellants' advocate.
Case triable by Special Judge under Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether pardon tendered to approver Ram Saran Das by District Magistrate under s. 337 CrPC was without jurisdiction as case triable by Special Judge.
Whether offence was under s. 222 IPC not s. 224 IPC, requiring sanction under s. 196A CrPC for conspiracy charge under s. 120B IPC.
Whether PW 6 Mela Ram and PW 7 Shiv Parshad were accomplices whose testimony could not corroborate approver.
Whether failure to hold test identification parade rendered identification evidence inadmissible.
Whether single charge contravened s. 233 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pardon to approver Ram Saran Das by District Magistrate under s. 337 CrPC without jurisdiction as case triable exclusively by Special Judge; approver's evidence inadmissible.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 337 CrPC; Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952

petitioner_arguments.text: Offence of conspiracy under s. 120B IPC relates to s. 222 IPC not s. 224 IPC; s. 222 non-cognizable, requires sanction under s. 196A CrPC.
PW 6 Mela Ram and PW 7 Shiv Parshad were accomplices on their own showing; their testimony could not be considered.
Charge as framed contravened mandatory provisions of s. 233 CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: Examined evidence of PW 6 and PW 7; nothing establishes them as accomplices; not urged before High Court; courts below entitled to believe them; no reason to differ.
No test identification parade held, but appellants known to police witnesses; identification by others admissible though weight for courts below; no exceptional grounds to reassess.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure does not make evidence inadmissible.

court_reasoning.text: Separate charges should have been framed per s. 233 CrPC but irregularity cured by s. 537 CrPC; objection raised but abandoned by appellants' advocate before Special Judge; public prosecutor objected but overruled at accused's request; no prejudice; not raised before High Court.
Even if offence under s. 222 not 224 IPC, academic if conviction under s. 5(2) PCA upheld; sanction under s. 196A not raised at trial or High Court; question of fact not entertainable now.

District Magistrate had authority under s. 337 CrPC as Special Judge deemed Court of Session per s. 8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952; s. 9 provides appeal as from Session Court; pardon valid even before amendment lowering threshold to 7 years; Special Judge's power under s. 8(2) does not deprive DM; case not yet before Special Judge.

holdings.text: Point 2 academic if PCA conviction affirmed.
District Magistrate authorised to tender pardon under s. 337 CrPC as Special Judge deemed Court of Session.

outcome.summary: All submissions on behalf of appellants rejected as having no substance; convictions and sentences under ss. 120B, 224/109 IPC and s. 5(2) PCA upheld; appeals dismissed.

key_quotes.text: It is clear from the findings of the courts below that M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody and the appellants had enabled him to do so and that they had received money as illegal gratification.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: for the purposes of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session trying cases without a jury or without the aid of assessors.
key_quotes.speaker: court
